channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Russia Sharply Raises Interest Rates as Wartime Financial Problems Pile Up
item.description: The country’s central bank raised interest rates 3.5 percentage points to stem rising prices and a weakening ruble. The move came after the national currency briefly fell below a key level with the U.S. dollar.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: The Hidden Trauma of Ukraine’s Soldiers
item.description: Facing a growing mental health crisis among soldiers, Ukraine’s therapists and doctors use a variety of treatments, but the need far outstrips the available care.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: There is a crisis of wounded psyches, in addition to broken bodies, among Ukrainian soldiers.

item.title: Xuxa Was Brazil’s Barbie. Now She’s Saying Sorry.
item.description: Xuxa was once Brazil’s biggest TV star. Now many are wondering whether a thin, blond, white woman was the right idol for such a diverse country.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Xuxa on a television show on the network Globo in the 1980s. She says she now laments the beauty standards she portrayed.

item.title: In Greece, a ‘Beach Towel Movement’ Fights for a Spot on the Sand
item.description: As lounge chairs that rent for up to $130 pop up across the islands, local people have decided they won’t take it lying down.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrating to “reclaim the beach” in July at Marcello and Krios beach on the island of Paros, Greece.

item.title: Typhoon Lan Brings Heavy Rain and Winds to Western Japan
item.description: The heavy rains and winds brought by the storm prompted evacuation warnings and the cancellation of hundreds of flights.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Heavy rain in Tanabe, Wakayama Prefecture, as Typhoon Lam hit, on Tuesday.

item.title: The Ukrainian Mechanics Who Fix Tanks at the War’s Frontline
item.description: Behind the thousands of troops fighting the counteroffensive are engineers and technicians who perform an essential, and often dangerous, job.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the 37th Marine Brigade repairing a vehicle near the front in southern Ukraine last month.

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Fire at Gas Station in Dagestan, Russia
item.description: Reports from news agencies said at least 35 people were killed and 66 hospitalized in Dagestan, but there were no immediate reports of foul play or of a connection to the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Emergency responders at the scene of the fire in Makhachkala, in the Dagestan region of Russia, on Monday night.

item.title: Roaring Back From Pandemic, Japan’s Economy Grows at 6% Rate
item.description: The rapid expansion came as exports have risen and tourists have flooded the country. But a drop in domestic consumption worried economists.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: While Japan’s economy has improved, domestic spending has not kept pace.

item.title: Dozens Said to Be Missing After Myanmar Jade Mine Landslide
item.description: The disaster occurred in Kachin State, where wildcat jade miners toil in dangerous conditions and landslides are common during the monsoon season.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Tarlin Mg/Ugc, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescue workers and onlookers at the site of the landslide in Kachin State in northern Myanmar on Sunday.

item.title: Far-Right Libertarian Wins Argentina’s Presidential Primary
item.description: Javier Milei, who wants to abolish the central bank and adopt the U.S. dollar as Argentina’s currency, is now the front-runner in the fall general election.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Natalie Alcoba and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:description: Javier Milei at his campaign headquarters in Buenos Aires on Sunday. He said he would “end the useless, parasitic, criminal political caste that is sinking this country.”

item.title: 9 Killed as Temple in India Is Hit by Landslide
item.description: At least 25 people may be trapped under the structure in the Himalayan state of Himachal Pradesh, officials said, as this year’s monsoon season continues to extract a deadly toll.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Monday searching for victims of a landslide that struck a temple in Himachal Pradesh State, India.

item.title: Taliban Fighters, Unsettled by Peace, Seek New Battles Abroad
item.description: Two years on from when the Taliban took Kabul, the outflow of young Talibs has renewed fears of violent extremism spilling across Afghanistan’s borders.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Peace and security have been secured in our country, so now we need to fight in other countries and secure the rights of other Muslims,” one Taliban fighter-turned-policeman, Wahdat, 22, right, said recently in Kabul.

item.title: Niger Junta Says It Will Prosecute Deposed President for Treason
item.description: Coup leaders also signaled they would be open to dialogue with West African nations, the first sign of a thaw after weeks of rising tensions.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: President Mohamed Bazoum of Niger has been kept isolated in his private residence with his wife and one of their sons.

item.title: North Korea Confirms Detention of Travis King, U.S. Soldier
item.description: The statement was the first public acknowledgment by the country that it has the soldier, Pvt. Travis King, in its custody.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A file image of a news program on the American soldier Travis King at the Seoul Railway Station in Seoul last month.

item.title: Russia’s Interest Rate Hike Highlights Economic Struggle Amid Ukraine War
item.description: With the third-largest interest rate increase in a decade to shore up the ruble, Moscow’s policymakers are pursuing the conflicting goals of paying for the war against Ukraine and taming inflation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow last month.

item.title: Can Koyo Kouoh Revive Zeitz MOCAA?
item.description: “There was a feeling that we cannot let this fail,” Koyo Kouoh said of taking the top job at Zeitz MOCAA. She wants to make it relevant to the Pan-African world and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.category: Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa
item.media:credit: Tsele Nthane for The New York Times
item.media:description: Koyo Kouoh, the executive director of the Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa, in Cape Town, S.A., with Lynette Yiadom-Boakye’s canvas, “11 p.m. Friday.”

item.title: U.K. Reveals 5 Espionage Arrests After BBC Reports Russia Link
item.description: Britain’s counterterrorism unit arrested the five on suspicion of spying on British intelligence, the authorities said following a BBC report that three of the same people had been accused of spying for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Police headquarters in London, formally called New Scotland Yard.

item.title: Families of 17 USS Cole Sailors Killed by Al Qaeda Await Justice at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: Families of the sailors who were killed in the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole and survivors having been making the trek to the war court at Guantánamo Bay for pretrial hearings since 2011.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sean Rayford for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I can’t name another case in United States history, a criminal case, that has taken 20 years to prosecute,” said Anton J. Gunn, whose brother Cherone was killed in the bombing at age 22.

item.title: At Least 3 Dead After Russian Missile Attacks in Western Ukraine
item.description: Officials said more than three dozen missiles were fired in the strikes that were far from the front lines in the east and south.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Rescuers working at a site of a Russian military strike in Lviv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Fires Warning Shots and Boards a Freighter in the Black Sea
item.description: Russia’s military made good on its threats to enforce its blockade of Ukraine, adding to the tensions in an increasingly active theater of war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Jenny Gross and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:credit: Center for Strategic Communications, via Reuters
item.media:description: A video shared widely, including by Ukraine’s government, showing a Russian helicopter hovering over the ship Sukru Okan in the Black Sea on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Ambassador Meets Evan Gershkovich, Detained WSJ Reporter, in Russia
item.description: American officials have said that their Russian counterparts are blocking them from getting regular consular access to Mr. Gershkovich.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: The U.S. ambassador to Russia, Lynne Tracy, after a hearing in Moscow in June to consider an appeal against the detention of Evan Gershkovich.

item.title: Latvia’s Prime Minister, Krisjanis Karins, Is to Resign
item.description: Krisjanis Karins had wanted to reshuffle his cabinet but was rebuffed by his governing coalition partners.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Krisjanis Karins of Latvia in Brussels last month. He said on Monday that the other parties in the coalition were “blocking work for welfare and economic growth.”

item.title: For Ukraine, Many Antiwar Activists in the U.S. Make an Exception
item.description: Several reasons might explain the differing response, including the fact that no American troops have been committed to the fight.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Ukraine demonstrating in Washington. Many activists who condemn war in general are supporting American efforts to defend Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Ruble Slides Past 100 Against the Dollar, Its Weakest Level Since March 2022
item.description: The currency weakened as far as 102 to the dollar, adding to concerns of inflation and prompting the Russian Central Bank to move quickly to consider raising rates.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova and Paul Sonne

item.title: As Russian forces mount an offensive, Ukrainians in Kupiansk fear a second occupation.
item.description: The torture rooms in the battered Ukrainian city of Kupiansk have been empty for months. But Moscow’s advancing forces are just five miles away.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: At the outset of the war, Kupiansk, only 25 miles from the Russian border, fell to Moscow’s forces before being retaken six months later during a lightning Ukrainian thrust in the Kharkiv region.

item.title: A Convict’s Life in Russia’s Army: ‘We Are Not Human to Them’
item.description: In an account provided to The Times, a Russian soldier describes his commanders’ casual disregard for the lives of inmates like him, and how they are pressured to re-enlist.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ekaterina Bodyagina
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A military vehicle with the Russian “Z” symbol in Oleksandrivka, Ukraine, this year.

item.title: Tourists Adapt to a Brutal Summer in Europe
item.description: Travelers are flocking to Europe this summer, but the excessive and prolonged heat is putting a crimp in their plans. Here’s what some are doing.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: Tourists visiting the Parthenon in Athens last month were greeted with temperatures that reached as high as 118 degrees Fahrenheit.

item.title: Russia is replicating Iranian drones and using them to attack Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: Parts of what was considered to be an Iranian-made Shahed-136 at a site in Kharkiv, Ukraine, last fall. Russia has begun manufacturing their own versions of the design.

item.title: Romania, a NATO neighbor of Ukraine, lies all too close to Russia’s strikes on Danube ports.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gheorghe Puflea, 71, said he was woken by the sounds of explosions and shattering glass when Russia attacked a port across the river from his shack in Plauru, Romania.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: The toll of devastating wildfires in Maui.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Much of Lahaina was destroyed by a fast-moving wildfire in western Maui, Hawaii.

item.title: ‘Barbie’ Debuts in Saudi Arabia, Sparking Delight, and Anger
item.description: Denounced in some Middle Eastern countries for undermining traditional gender norms, the hit movie is finding an audience in Saudi Arabia, illustrating the region’s shifting political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: The “Barbie” movie opened in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Thursday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Appoints Envoy to Palestinians Amid Push for Ties With Israel
item.description: The Saudi foreign ministry said its ambassador to Jordan would jointly serve as an envoy to the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Arab neighborhoods in Israeli-occupied East Jerusalem. Saudi Arabia recognizes Palestinian statehood across the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.

item.title: Nechama Tec, Polish Holocaust Survivor and Scholar, Dies at 92
item.description: She wrote about heroic Jewish resisters in her book “Defiance,” which was later made into a film starring Daniel Craig and Liev Schreiber.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Nechama Tec in 2018 at her home in Manhattan. A sociologist, she wrote about Jews as resisters of the Nazis and why certain people became rescuers

item.title: Italians Pay Tribute to Novelist and Activist Who Spoke Out Till the End
item.description: Michela Murgia was a voice for minorities and a lightning rod for political debate. She also garnered respect even from a prime minister whose policies she opposed.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Vargiu/Mondadori Portfolio/Sipa USA, via Reuters
item.media:description: After announcing in May that she had cancer, Michela Murgia emphasized the importance of living life to the full.

item.title: Deadly Boat Wreck in Senegal Caused by Patrols Chasing Migrants
item.description: Patrol vessels were pursuing a fishing boat loaded with migrants bound for Spain when it struck rocks off a beach in Senegal’s capital, locals say, leaving at least 16 people dead.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Mady Camara
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: An open wooden fishing boat that struck rocks off a beach in Dakar, Senegal’s capital, was still partly submerged in the water four days later.

item.title: Iran’s Ashura Rituals Have Become a New Form of Protest
item.description: Ashura, which mourns the killing of the Prophet Muhammad’s grandson and celebrates Shiite identity, has long symbolized the fight against oppression. This year, its chants have been turned against the government.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Arash Khamooshi
item.media:description: Last month in Tehran a group of men commemorated Ashura, Shiite Islam’s most sacred ritual, showcased annually with great fanfare.

item.title: Without F-16s, Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Is Missing a Key Piece
item.description: Most military experts doubt that they would have, and say that Kyiv can still prevail without them.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Dutch Air Force F-16 fighter jets over the Netherlands in July. The Biden administration waited over a year before agreeing to have NATO countries send F-16s to Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Strikes Kill 7 in Ukrainian Region Under Ceaseless Shelling
item.description: Ukrainian officials said two children and their parents were among the dead after the attacks on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian demining engineers last month in an abandoned village in the Kherson region, which has been subjected to relentless Russian bombardment.

item.title: Rome’s Umbrella Pines Are in Danger
item.description: While an invasive insect bears much of the blame for endangering a beloved symbol of Rome, critics are also pointing the finger at city government.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rome’s signature umbrella pine trees are as much of part of the city’s identity as its human-made landmarks.

item.title: Climber Defends Finishing K2 Climb After Finding Dying Sherpa
item.description: One of the climbers, Kristin Harila, said she continued her summit of the mountain after finding a porter who fell from a cliff and later died.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: Kristin Harila and her guide, Tenjin Sherpa, in Kathmandu, Nepal, this month.

item.title: Anwaar-ul-Haq Kakar Appointed Interim Prime Minister of Pakistan
item.description: The announcement comes amid growing speculation that elections — once expected to happen this fall — will be delayed until 2024.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum

item.title: Ukraine Makes Progress in Its Counteroffensive
item.description: Troops advanced several miles along two main lines of attack in Kyiv’s drive to reach the southern coast and sever Russian supply lines, while explosions echoed at the vital Kerch Strait Bridge.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers preparing an armored Humvee before heading to the southern front line.

item.title: A Withering Assessment of a Multibillion-Dollar Real Estate Windfall
item.description: Ontario’s auditor general found that the process to open up land in Toronto’s Greenbelt was influenced by and favored two developers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Ford is not backing down from a plan to open some of Toronto’s Greenbelt to development.

item.title: Lai Ching-te of Taiwan’s Visit to U.S. Will Be Closely Watched
item.description: An outspoken critic of Beijing, Lai Ching-te aims to reassure voters and Washington that he will be a safe pair of hands if elected.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate William Lai during the party congress in Taipei, Taiwan, in July.

item.title: In Istanbul, Tombs of Religious Figures Still Draw Pilgrims
item.description: Turkey’s largest city is dotted with the tombs of religious figures, where pilgrims seek divine intervention. “When you ask for something from God, those who are beloved by God can be a go-between.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Gulsin Harman and Ivor Prickett
item.media:description: Visitors praying at the shrine of Telli Baba, or the Father of the Threads, in Istanbul.

item.title: Zelensky Called Him a Criminal. Now Ukraine Calls Him for Guns and Ammo.
item.description: In its hunt for weapons, Ukraine has rolled back anticorruption rules and turned to people once seen as relics of an anything-goes era.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serhiy Pashinsky in his office in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Sex Segregation in Israel Grows, Raising Fears for Women’s Rights
item.description: Ultra-Orthodox members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition want to expand the powers of all-male rabbinical courts, and to bar women and men from mixing in many public arenas.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An ultra-Orthodox man in Bnei Brak, Israel, passing a sign that urges men not to look at women in the street or in some other social settings.

item.title: Americans Held Prisoner in Iran Saw Promise of Better Relations
item.description: The five Americans who are part of a prisoner swap could be released by September under a complicated agreement with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Siamak Namazi in Berlin in 2015, the year he was detained by Iranian authorities.

item.title: Ukraine Fires Top Military Enlistment Officers After Bribery Scandal
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said he was removing all 24 regional recruitment chiefs, as corrupt draft evasion schemes put the confidence of the public and Ukraine’s Western backers at risk.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recruits take part in a drill during training at an undisclosed location in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region in July.

item.title: Biden Describes China as a Time Bomb Over Economic Problems
item.description: The sharply worded comments are the latest example of the president’s willingness to criticize China even as he tries to ease tensions.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden has signaled that he continues to view Beijing as America’s biggest economic competitor.

item.title: Fresh Fighting in Ethiopia Raises Fears of New War
item.description: Less than a year after the war in the country’s northern Tigray region ended, Ethiopia’s military is battling an ethnic militia in the neighboring Amhara region in a part of Africa already ravaged by conflict.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Ethiopia’s prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, earlier this year. The recent clashes there follow monthslong tensions over Mr. Abiy’s proposal to dismantle special regional forces nationwide.

item.title: Tanker in Yemen Is Emptied of Oil, Averting Catastrophic Spill
item.description: More than a million barrels of oil on a tanker off the coast of Yemen were transferred to another ship bought by the United Nations. But now a new hurdle looms: Who owns the recovered oil?
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: An oil worker on the deck of the FSO Safer off the coast of Yemen last month. Crew members worked in soaring summer temperatures to transfer the oil to a newer ship.

item.title: When art and money meet
item.description: Encouragement, profit or exploitation?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Larry Gagosian at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., last year.

item.title: U.K. Evacuates Asylum Seekers From Barge Over Bacteria in Water
item.description: Bacteria that can cause Legionnaires’ disease were found on the Bibby Stockholm, a barge that began housing migrants this week as part of a hard-line government policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The barge Bibby Stockholm, moored on England’s south coast, took its first asylum seekers on board on Monday.

item.title: What Another Trump Presidency Could Mean for Australia
item.description: The author of a new book exploring that possibility says it would raise existential questions about the current alliance with America, with huge implications for Australia’s regional and global standing.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Donald Trump is the front-runner to be the Republican candidate in the 2024 presidential election.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Released From South Africa Prison After Brief Return
item.description: The authorities said Mr. Zuma, the former president, was a beneficiary of a new program to relieve crowding. His political opponents called the timing suspicious.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Jerome Delay/Pool/Agence France-Presse via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, in court last year. Mr. Zuma had served just two months of a 15-month sentence for defying a court order to testify before a national inquiry on corruption.

item.title: Ukrainians in Kupiansk Fear a Second Russian Occupation
item.description: The torture rooms in the battered Ukrainian city of Kupiansk have been empty for months. But Moscow’s advancing forces are just five miles away.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: At the outset of the war, Kupiansk, only 25 miles from the Russian border, fell to Moscow’s forces before being retaken six months later during a lightning Ukrainian thrust in the Kharkiv region.

item.title: Russian Influencer Ksenia Sobchak on the War: Resistance Is Futile, So Find Ways to Cope
item.description: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best known media figures still in Russia, says her fatalistic stance just reflects a grim reality. Some liberals call her a Kremlin stooge, while hawks see her as disloyal.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Maria Contreras Coll for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best-known media figures still based in Russia, has called on Russians to just accept the war. She was interviewed while on vacation in Spain last month.

item.title: China’s Military, ‘Chasing the Dream,’ Probes Taiwan’s Defenses
item.description: Day by day, the People’s Liberation Army is turning up the pressure, deploying an ever-wider array of planes and ships.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chinese naval vessel near Dongju Island, Taiwan, in April. Beijing claims Taiwan as its territory, to be unified with force if necessary.

item.title: A Japanese Candy Tasted Like Nothing. Why Do People Miss It?
item.description: Flavorless (?) Candy, a convenience store product in Japan, spurred debate over what the “taste of nothingness” tastes like, if anything.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
